div.head: HUMBOLDT AND DE BUCH.
div.p:
Science has lost a distinguished apostle in the person of
the celebrated geologist, Baron Christian Leopold von
Buch, who died at Berlin on the 4th instant, after a few
days’ illness, in his 79th year. The melancholy event is
thus announced to Sir Richard Murchison, by von Buch’s
venerable friend and fellow-student, Alexander von Hum-
boldt. We were unavoidably obliged, by pressure of space,
to omit this interesting document from last week’s publica-
tion:—

That I should be destined—I, an old man of 83— to
announce to you, dear Roderick, the saddest news that I
could have to convey—to you for whom M. de Buch pro-
fessed a friendship so tender—and to the many admirers of
his genius, his vast labours, and his noble character!
Leopold De Buch was taken from us this morning by
typhoid fever—so violent in its attack that two days only
of danger warned us. He was at my house so lately as the
26th ult., despite the snow and the distance between us—
talking geology with the most lively interest. That evening
he went into society, and on Sunday and Monday (the 27th
and 28th) he complained of a feverish swelling from which
he had suffered for years. The inflammation required the
application of leeches—but the pain and the fever in-
creased. He was speechless for 38 hours. ... He
died surrounded by his friends, most of whom knew
nothing of his danger till Wednesday evening, the 2nd of
March. He and I were united by a friendship of 63
years—a friendship which never knew interruption. I
found him in 1791, in Werner’s house in Freiberg, when I
entered the School of Mines. We were together in Italy,
in Switzerland, in France, four months in Saltzburg. M.
De Buch was not only one of the great illustrations of his
age—he was a man of noble soul. His mind left a track
of light—he could boast of having extended the limits of
geological science. I grieve for him profoundly—without
him I feel desolate. I consulted him as muster; and his
affection (like that of Gay Lussac and that of Arago, who
were also his friends) sustained me in my labours. He was
four years my junior—and nothing forewarned me of this
misfortune. It is not at the distance of a few hours only
from such a loss that I can say more respecting it. Pity
me—and accept the homage of my profound respect and
affectionate devotion.
